mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] Character to Entities for javadoc

But this function is not available for java mode and I did not find the same function in another plugin nor in a macro. Any idea about the best approach ? Michaël

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Character to Entities for javadoc
mail.body: What would you like ? numeric encoding, like &#e9, accepted in all XML documents; or html entities, like &eacute; ? In both cases, XMLPlugin can certainly be extended to not be so picky about the current mode : to their escaped notation I'm in favour of the first solution, since it will never create meaningless entities. By any way, please register a plugin feature request... Best regards, Le 27/01/10 21:53, Michaël Michaud a écrit :

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Character to Entities for javadoc
mail.body: Hi Thanks for answering I'm not an xml/html expert. I know that html entities work fine for javadoc. Never tried numeric entities, but from what I read, it should work. First solution seems OK (not sure what your second solution means) OK, done. Michaël PS : surfing a bit on internet about this problem, I just read that javadoc should understand unicode escape characters like \u0040 ... and jEdit has a good macro to escape unicode characters ;-)/ /

mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] jEdit never appears if ftp server is dead
mail.body: I have been tracking down a problem where I launch jEdit, and the editor never appears on the screen. I think I understand (partly) what's happening. I am using the FTP and sessions plugins. When I last closed down jEdit, all of the files it had open were on an SFTP server. The server has apparently died (I just tried to log into it using another program, and confirmed that it's not up). I managed to get jEdit running (and appearing on my screen) by temporarily moving the files in .jedit/jar to a temp dir (that was probably overkill, but at the time I didn't know what was going on). If from this running instance of jEdit, I try to open a file on the dead server, it eventually times out, giving an I/O Error, as it should. But AFAICT, if jEdit tries to open files on this server at jEdit's startup, it never times out. I have to admit that I'm not sure that it *never* times out. It was trying to open around 15 files on the dead server; so if it did this in sequence, waiting for each file to time out before trying the next, I suppose maybe I didn't wait long enough, although I did wait an awfully long time. Still, if that's what's happening, it would be nice if it would display *something* (like the editor itself, and individual I/O error msgs); otherwise, it appears as if jEdit is simply dead. This is jEdit 4.3 server mode, Java 1.6.0_17, Windows Vista SP2. --

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] jEdit never appears if ftp server is dead
mail.body: Maybe you should make a bug entry about this issue. Just some hints for the usage. You can set up jEdit to not restore remote files on startup to prevent a dead FTP server from causing jEdit not to start up. This setting you can also simply change in ~/.jedit/properties by searching for the entry "restore.remote=" and setting it to false. And instead of moving the contents of ~/.jedit/jars, you can simply use the command line option "-noplugins" to start jEdit without loading any plugins. Alternately you could use the command line option "-norestore" no open jEdit without reopening any previously opened files for that invocation. Mike Maxwell schrieb:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Creating/adding new template files in SuperAbbrevs Plugin ..
mail.body: If I remember correctly the SuperAbbrevs templates are simply serialized Java Maps. The easiest way to create new templates is to use the plugin's options interface. Go to "Plugins" -> "Plugin Options" -> "SuperAbbrevs": "Abbreviations". Select the mode you want, Eg. actionscript, and click the "Add..." button at the bottom (The little plus sign). Detailed instructions on creating abbreviations are included with the plugin. "Help" -> "jEdit Help (F1)" -> "Plugins": SuperAbbrevs. You might find it helpful to write the template in a new jEdit buffer first, then copy and paste it into the Abbreviation Creation window. mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] start failure
mail.body: The problem is with the install process On Thu, Jan 14, 2010 at 8:04 AM, e-letter <inpost@...> wrote: You have a problem with your installation of jEdit. That is why it is not starting correctly. I would recommend using the platform-independent install jar and installing it AS your own user IN your user directory and running that instead. Then at least you won't have any permissions issues and can run the thing. You haven't said anywhere how you installed 4.3 in the first place. Was it a deb or a jar file? And I don't care if you can "start up" an older previously installed version of jEdit. All that means is that you installed it once correctly before. Finally, you might want to start with clean settings in your ~/.jedit directory. If the installer has a bug, you need to give a descriptive bug report that is helpful, otherwise it won't ever get fixed. None of the developers run the installer on a regular basis so we don't see bugs there as often as new users do.

I've been using jEdit for a long time, and there has been at least one occasion where I found it didn't work right, and when I researched it, it turned out to be a bug in Sun's JDK. And if you pay twice as much for jEdit, you get twice the dedicated tech support people ready at their phone lines to accept your support call.

mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] filemanagers invoke jEdit, but text file not loaded
mail.body: This question was asked a few days ago in the Troubleshooting forum, but without any replies, so I thought I'd ask it again here. I've been using jEdit 4.3pre14 under Max OS X.4.11 (Tiger), and it has worked fine. Very recently I moved to OS X.6.2 (Snow Leopard), which uses Java 1.6.0_17, and installed jEdit 4.3 Stable. It works okay except for a couple of peculiarities: * using any one of the 3 file managers - Finder, Path Finder, muCommandrr - when I double-click on a text file, jEdit comes up but the text file it- self is not loaded into it. The file has to be loaded with C-o. * when I load a file to edit I can Paste any one of the items in the multi- item clipboard (Jumpcut), but once I select and Copy some text in the file, only that item is pasted regardless of the which item I actually chose in the clipboard. If I close that window and reload the file from the Recent list, I can again Paste any item I want from the clipboard. Anyone have any ideas what might be going one with either of these mis- behaviors, or suggestions for where to investigate? Thanks. - Dushan

mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] jCompiler and xilize : abandonned ?
mail.body: Hi, while browsing the list of the plugins I have found that jCompiler has interesting features and I would like to look at it closer. But it is not available via the plugin manager and both the last release date and the requirements seems to indicate that it is abandonned. Is it the case, or maybe it has bee superseded by another plugin ? BTW, I have a similar question concerning the xilize plugin that keeps crashing for months on both OSX and Win XP while passing the mouse on its entry in the plugin menu (I know, I should have done a bug report, but I am lurking the mailing-list sine only a couple of weeks) Regards.

mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] Files not closing
mail.body: Often when I close a modified file and elect not to save changes, I get prompted again about my unsaved changes when I go to quit jEdit. I don't see the file in my list of buffers, but I may still receive notifications if another program modifies it - as if jEdit still has it open but hidden. Anyone else have this problem? Thanks, Sarah

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Check jEdit version plugin
mail.body: The latestversion plugin is obsolete. I would recommend you try the "updater" plugin instead. Perhaps we should package the updater with jEdit instead of latestversion from now on? On Wed, Jan 13, 2010 at 7:43 AM, Marcin Orlowski <carlos@...> wrote:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Check jEdit version plugin
mail.body: +1 from me on this. The Updater plugin is very useful for this. -- Learn from the past. Live in the present. Plan for the future. 11101000

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Check jEdit version plugin
mail.body: In general I agree, but I think that before we do that, the Updater plugin user interface should be simpler and more friendly, e.g. a progress dialog with a "More" button to show the text pane. Currently the text pane is all it provides. Shlomy 2010/1/13 Eric Berry <elberry@...>:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Check jEdit version plugin

mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] Switching between buffers
mail.body: Hi I have been using Eclipse for a while, and in Eclipse, if you press Ctrl+Tab, it brings up a list of all the open files in the editor, with the current file first, then the previous one, then the one active before that and so on. I've become used to this, and I still use Eclipse a lot when editing php-code. But one project I code using jEdit, and I really miss this functionality. I can find/set shortcuts to switch to the previous buffer, this makes the current buffer the 'previous' buffer, thus, I can switch between two buffers easily. But, I would really like a shortcut to switch buffers sort of like the Eclipse-method. I've tried different buffer-switching plugins, but I cannot get any of them to switch like this. The bufferlist plugin can switch between open buffers using a shortcut, but it always go to the next or previous buffer in the list, and the list is not reordered when a buffer is activated. -- Mads Lie Jensen - mads@... - ICQ #25478403 Gartneriet -

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] zen coding: ridiculously awesome for html
mail.body: Entering. But what about maintaining, which is the majority of site development effort? Template engines are a much better choice and better practice, than using text editor macros for creating html - it is just too easy to abuse. If it is too easy to type, you'll be more likely to copy'n'paste code. Bert

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] zen coding: ridiculously awesome for html
mail.body: you have WYSIWYG html editors that allow you to do these things with almost no typing? (e.g. Microsoft Office as well as many open source html editors). WYSWIG unfortunately always suck if you want do something correctly, any WYSWIG I saw to date produces crappy output. And once you learn HTML syntax and practice you will be more effective with jEdit than more users with WYSWIG. PS: MS Office a good WYSWIG editor? mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] New Daily - Launcher
mail.body: The Launcher plugin has been added to the Daily builds. [quote From the Launcher plugin description] The Launcher plugin provides a way to add the same context specific menu to the File System Browser, ProjectViewer, Plugin Menu, and text area contextual menu. The contents of this menu is dynamic and depends on the current selection or buffer. This menu offers various ways of launching the selected resource(s). For example: Launchers are organized by LauncherTypes, which manage launchers that: Note that the same Launcher can be used by many LauncherTypes. For example on most systems one can find a command line tool that is able to open a file with its associated application and also open a url with the default browser (desktop settings). On x11 system this application is 'xdg-open', on Mac OS X 'open', and on Windows 'start'. At startup the Launcher plugin determines which OS is being used and defines the corresponding SystemApplicationOrBrowserLauncher. The latter will then be used by BrowserLauncherType and SystemApplicationLauncherType. More precisely the Launcher plugin proposes a framework for defining Launchers and managing them via LauncherTypes. Both of these classes are services whereby other plugins can contribute new Launchers and LauncherTypes. Launchers are an extension of the EditAction type. They are typically stateless therefore the same instance is reused in different places. [/quote] -- Learn from the past. Live in the present. Plan for the future. 11101000

Maybe you want to try those to your parser, I got those examples from a page that also demonstrates them. I don't think that you can also do ".t1:not(.t2)" because .t1 is a class, not an element. You can find more information and examples about CSS3 negation at Regards Vampire Dale Anson schrieb:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] start failure with IBM JRE
mail.body: Perhaps a middle ground: IBM JRE has known issues which may be found at xxx. The Sun JRE is the reference implementation, it is also the most commonly used JRE. If I were the author of jedit (I wish!) I would have said upfront in the very early days that the only supported JRE is Sun. As a developer I've had compatibility issues even with Sun, taking the time to try to support all the engines is just not practical. It is noble enough to open source a complex, quality product like jedit, it is over the top to expect these same people to support a plethora of JREs. Tracking down JRE compatibility issues can take a lot of time that is basically unproductive. Fixing them can often break the reference (Sun) implementation. Remember PC-DOS? It was 90% compatible with MS-DOS. IBM is famous for tricks like this. The open source community should not be pandering to the special quirks of commercial offerings. If company xyz is ambitious enough to publish a JRE/SDK, at the very least they should run all the tests that Sun runs and certify it as being compliant to the published standards. That would spare users the problems when someone tries to take something written to the standard and run it on one of these odd birds. mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] start failure
mail.body: Hi, I don't think anyone refuses to support other Java implementations (otherwise, no one would have replied your requests). The thing is, most developers have only Sun Java installed and will not install additional Java versions to ensure it works with them (for various reasons). While we want to help users, our resources are limited. If anyone is willing to cooperate in testing jEdit for IBM Java (or OpenJDK), they are most welcome. We'd like jEdit to be supported as widely as possible, but we need help from the jEdit community for that. If jEdit is valuable for you, and you have to use IBM Java for whatever reason, you're more than welcome to help with testing and reporting problems, with enough data that would enable us to fix the problems without installing IBM Java on our machines. mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] Call for votes: What development task do you want to prioritize?
mail.body: Dear jEdit users, After we got the new stable release of 4.3 (and 4.3.1), we (core developers) became not sure what development task should we prioritize as a team. So we want to know what users want. The question is: If the priorities became clear, we can work more efficiently as a team to achieve the goal. Please send your answer to <jedit-users@...>. Just sending a reply will do that. If you find an answer from another user which you can agree, please send your "+1" to prioritize it more. Followings are some information about the question. There are many development tasks. For example, implementing new features, fixing bugs, planning the next release, cleaning the codes, updating docs, reviewing patches, etc. These are lists of open tracker items. We are happy if you provide the item ID related to your answer. This is a link to the most up to date list of things have been done after the release of 4.3. Thank your for your appreciation. -- k_satoda

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Call for votes: What development task do you want to prioritize?
mail.body: wrote: If I may butt in here--I do a lot of editing of middling to large XML files (10k lines, some much longer). The indentation is not consistent: some of the files are produced by another application, which cares nothing about human-readable files. (While I could run a beautifier over the files, we keep them in a version control system, and doing beautification would result in a massive number of changes, most of them irrelevant.) So if I want to use folding based on the XML structure, I have to do it with SideKick's XML parser. I've turned off the "Auto parsing Settings" in SideKick for all except "Parse on buffer save", as things bog down too much otherwise. I don't know that there's a solution to this; parsing > 10k lines of XML (or any other programming language) is probably going to take awhile regardless of optimization (although I would love to be proved wrong!). But I mention this in case it's a reason why jEdit appears slow to some people; if it is, changing the SideKick AutoParse settings may make life easier.

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] how to search for a whole word

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Installing jEdit 4.3.1 on top of 4.2 Pre 17 under Vista x64
mail.body: As there was no such thing as 4.2pre17 I assume you mean 4.3pre17. There are several ways to end the jEdit server. - Close jEdit not with the red X in the upper right, but use File->Exit, that will exit jEdit completely - Use the Startmenu entry "Stop jEdit server" if you installed the Startmenu shortcuts - Type "jedit -quit" at the command line All three individually should close jEdit completely. Btw. in the processes list it is one of your "java.exe" processes. I don't know the task menager in Vista, but if it cannot show the command line a process was started with, you could use a more decent process manager like "Process Explorer" from Sysinternals ( good software, as the just bought it and distribute it themselves now. mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] Creating a customised jEdit OSX build.
mail.body: Hi, I'm looking for some advice on creating my own pre-customised jEdit that I can give to friends who want to try out jEdit. Is there a way to package up my settings and plugins into a standalone jEdit.app ? Any ideas are welcome. :-) Regards, Dennis

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Creating a customised jEdit OSX build.
mail.body: Hi Dennis, there are many ways to do that or something similar. Here some options: - open the jEdit.app folder with "Show content" from the context menu and copy the settings and plugins that you want to have "pre-packaged" there, then send around the jEdit.app or build a (internet enabled) DMG for it - use the plugin manager to install the plugins you want to have "pre-packaged" not to the settings but to the jEdit directory, then they should land automatically in the jEdit.app, then open the jEdit.app folder with "Show content" from the context menu and copy the settings that you want to have "pre-packaged" there, then send around the jEdit.app or build a (internet enabled) DMG for it - export your plugin set via plugin manager as plugin set and distribute that exported file and your settings file. With the plugin set your friends can install that same set of plugins automatically by importing the plugin set from within plugin manager and the settings file has just to be placed inside the settings directory - distribute your whole settings folder to your friends (take care about what you distribute, some plugins store cache data there that only would need space, some plugins store passwords there) - download or checkout the source and modify the build process so that the settings and plugins you want are included, then call "ant dist-mac" There are possibly a dozen other ways to do what you want to do, it is a matter of taste how you want to do it. The simplest and easiest way is maybe to export your plugin set and give them your settings file. Regards Vampire PS: To get your settings file, either just pick "properties" from your settings folder (by default ~/.jedit) or use the macro "Properties->jEdit Properties" to dump the settings to a new buffer and save that buffer Dennis Hotson schrieb:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Creating a customised jEdit OSX build.
mail.body: Hi Dennis, of course you can. Again there are multiple ways. The most important ones are maybe: - change the default location of the settings directory if you rebuild from source - use the startup parameter with which you can define a custom settings directory. I'm not sure if you can set this up in the plist but maybe this is possible. Regards Vampire Dennis Hotson schrieb:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Creating a customised jEdit OSX build.
mail.body: Hi, another note regarding settings: All settings of Global Option pane and most in Plugin Option pane are saved to the "properties" file. Properties that should apply to all user profiles can be separated (manually) to anyname.props files, witch have to be placed into the JEDIT_HOME\properties directory. For example, I have a shortcuts.props file where all my non-standard shortcuts are assigned. I can delete my user settings directory, and at next jedit start all my shortcuts are working... Robert

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Creating a customised jEdit OSX build.
mail.body: Thanks again, I think I've got it worked out now. OSX users can try it out here: I ended up taking the default jEdit.app and editing the contents. There were a couple of things I had to edit in the Info.plist to get it working. Added property: user.home=./ Added arguments: -noserver -settings=usersettings Also set the WorkingDirectory to: $APP_PACKAGE/Contents/Resources/Java I copied over my properties into a dhotson.props file in the properties dir as well. .. the result is a totally self contained jEdit.app with my settings as the default. The user settings directory is also inside the app so it won't interfere with your existing setup. I also wrote a short blog post about jEdit and some of the customisations I've made: .. feedback is welcome. :-) Cheers, Dennis Hotson On Sat, Mar 13, 2010 at 6:06 AM, Vampire (jEdit) <Vampire0@...> wrote:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Slow with large files (was: Call for votes: What development task do you want to prioritize?)
mail.body: On Thu, 29 Apr 2010 15:55:20 -0500, Sarah Cranston pretty Is this an XML file? FWIW, I tried to edit a 700,000 line XML file (it's a dictionary) in jEdit 4.3.1 the other day. It loaded fine, but when I tried to jump to the end of the file, jEdit froze, and still appeared to be frozen two hours later. I killed jEdit, and re-started it. But before I went anywhere in that file, I turned off all the "Auto parsing settings" in the SideKick plugin. Now I can jump to the end of the file the first time in five seconds or so, and after that virtually instantaneously. Every line in this file is an open or close tag, or a complete element, so there must be several 100k elements in the file. I'm not surprised SideKick takes awhile to digest it. I do notice, however, that even with SideKick's auto parsing turned off, I can still put the cursor on the beginning or end tag of the root XML element, and jump to its mate with "go to matching tag or bracket", in under a second. So in some sense jEdit still *has* parsed the entire file. Which makes me wonder what it is that SideKick is doing besides parsing the XML.

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Call for votes: What development task do you want to prioritize?
mail.body: It's the Sidekick settings -- Plugins - Plugin Options - Sidekick that govern code completion in general Check the auto parse and code completion settings, code completion only works well when 'parse on keystroke' is selected, but this is also the source of performance issues with large files. You also need the XML plugin for code completion to work for xml and html files. If you have the XML plugin disabled, you won't get code completion for these files. The XML plugin configuration (Plugins - Plugin options - XML - XML) has settings on when to insert closing tags. Dale On Wed, Apr 7, 2010 at 9:27 AM, maxwell <maxwell@...> wrote:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Abbreviations and % of file
mail.body: Ok, so you want to use only your custom abbrevs and with automatic replacement switched on. Of course this makes sense, I just wanted to know your motivation out of interest while I had a look in the code. :-) All the abbrevs, your custom ones and the default ones (read: the current set of abbrevs) is stored in the file "abbrevs" in your settings directoy (by default ~/.jedit). If this file exists, all abbrevs (and only those) contained in that file are loaded. If it doesn't exists, the default abbrevs are loaded and stored in that file. So just go to "Utilities -> Settings Directory -> abbrevs" and remove the lines you don't want to have. Then save that file and restart jEdit. The other way is to remove them one after each other through the GUI. Btw. about the percentage display. This can not be activated currently. Please see the following discussions: If you feel the need for having it back, you could make a comment in those threads on the devel mailing list or you could enter a Feature Request. Regards Vampire Troy S schrieb:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Abbreviations and % of file
mail.body: Sure. You can do two things. You can either assign S+F12 to add-marker-shortcut and F12 to goto-marker. Then you can press that key-combo and after that the one char shortcut to set or goto the according marker. If you really want to set the 'a' shortcut marker automatically, you can also do that. Just create two macros, one with content [quote] [/quote] and one with content [quote] [/quote] Then you can assign those macros to the key combos you want to use. That you could have find out by recording a (temporary or permanent) macro through the Macros menu and then performing the according actions. Regards Vampire Troy S schrieb:

mail.body: Dear jEdit-on-the-Mac users, I've been considering this bug : 1488911 Forward slash in path causes problems on OSX I've found a solution, but it implies that if you are typing paths using colons as directory separators instead of slashes, they won't work anymore. On the other hand, you will then be able to access files or directories containing slashes... So, are you typing things like "Mac HD:Documents:myfile" in the File System Browser, relying on jEdit to translate them to "/Documents/myfile" ? If nobody objects, I'll commit the patch to jEdit. mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] are there users of old MacOS paths out there ?
mail.body: Well, there is indeed an issue with path lists. File.pathSeparator == ":" on OSX. But for folder or file names containing slashes, the slashes are converted to colons and Java understands it. This is the BSD view of the filesystem. Mac OS X is quite unique in this respect. And canonPath() is already broken for problematic paths... Cheers, Eric Le 01/04/10 23:38, Eric Berry a écrit :

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Ctagsinterface searching
mail.body: Hi, For some reason, gmail removed the bullets from the original email when I clicked "reply". Please note that I am currently changing CtagsInterface to use Lucene (full text search engine) instead of a relational database for storing the tag database. There are several reasons for this change - it improves performance greatly, and provides a lot of flexibility in tag lookup (e.g. you can use fuzzy searches, where you don't remember the precise name of a tag). The is a very large change and affects most of the answers. 1. This is possible with the trunk version, but not with the released version. CtagsInterface has 'dynamic actions' that allow you to write queries that will result in tags to jump to. A few weeks ago, someone contributed a patch that allows you to use these queries also for the "Search for a tag with prefix" popup. When you enter the query, you can select whether you want to jump to the tag that is produced as a result of the query, or open this popup with the results. Using this feature, you can write a query that will find all functions, and have the popup let you choose only between functions. However, this is not a good solution, as most likely you'll have numerous functions to select from. Once I'm done porting CtagsInterface to Lucene, this will be much simpler, as Lucene queries are much more flexible. I'll be able to enhance this popup to support Lucene queries. 2. Case-insensitive search will be enabled when the port to Lucene is completed. 3. "Search for substring" is also case-sensitive. It should work fine, but it can take a lot of time, as the plugin creates a data structure in-memory to support this (this is one of the reasons why I am switching to Lucene). "Search with prefix" has no wildcards support as of now. 4. I am not sure about the Tags plugin. CtagsInterface also has an option to "import" an existing tag file, however I think that Tags supports tag files on VFS (e.g. ftp), while CtagsInterface currently only supports tag files on locally-mounted file-systems. If your tag files are local, no need to use Tags. If your sources are in locally-mounted file-systems only, there is also no need to use tag files, as CtagsInterface will run Ctags for you and keep the tag information up-to-date automatically. 5. To use the completion, type the prefix of a function name and select this action. It should show a small completion popup. Note that this is also case sensitive. In general, note that if you can type the entire function name and jump to it using the plugin, then typing a prefix of the function name and selecting this action should include the entire name in the completion options. For functions, this should also complete the signature (i.e. show you templates for the parameters, using the SuperAbbrevs plugin). The downside of the switch to Lucene is, that you'll have to delete your existing tag database and recreate it from scratch using Lucene. The advantages with Lucene are huge, so it's worth it ... Shlomy 2010/5/29 RolandD Cyber Produksi <contact@...>:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Errors showing in status bar
mail.body: I hate those error messages! damn them all. Why do we have to have any errors in this program?? :-) The idea is, if you found a condition under which you can reproduce the error, then you might actually file a bug report, tell us the steps you took to reproduce it, and that would help us fix the error so it doesn't show up anymore. On the other hand, if you do expect some sort of message to report when you do something wrong, you could suggest that we pop up as a dialog with a message that says "DON'T DO THAT YOU DUMMY!". But in any case, the stack trace and activity log are key to helping us understand what you did. alan, who should be asleep but is too jetlagged to know any better...

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Errors showing in status bar
mail.body: I totally understand the error requirements in regards to error reporting, but surely better to mimic what Windows or OSX does? There should be two types of error: 1) Expected error: This should ALWAYS be dealt with in a user-friendly way... i.e. if the auto-save feature tries to save my untitled document in a unix folder where I don't have permissions then a dialog (as you said) should say "Can't autosave 'untitled 1' to /usr/bin. Click here to turn off autosave for untitled files, OR you might think about running jEdit as root if you need to save a file in that locaiton". That's just an example error message but it's far more constructive, as it: a) Tells the user exactly what has happened in clear terms. b) It tells them possible options to improve the situation without needing to Google or go online! 2) Unexpected error (but catchable in some way): Tell the user an unexpected error has occurred (in a dialog if possible) and ask them if they want to automatically report the error (as XP and OSX do). Then it automatically downloads all the relevant error logs without a user needing to find them. This is MUCH better. The easier it is for users to report errors, the better for everyone, it really is a win-win situation. 3) Unexpected error (but non-catchable, i.e. total crash) however jEdit might be able to do a "Firefox" and know that it crashed next time it starts up, if so then do the same as 2) 4) Unexpected error (totally non-catchable, system doesn't know it crashed): This would rely on the user posting the error logs. I would recommend adding a really simple (Send Error Report) item on one of the menus (if it doesn't already exist). This automatically adds the error logs, and asks the user what actually happened. I think having to register for the PRIVILEGE of reporting errors is lame. I have about eight thousand different accounts with eight thousand different passwords just for reporting bugs on software... this is NOT cool. This needs to change in the freeware industry. As I said the easier it is to report bugs the better. The same level of detail can be captured now but please please PLEASE make it so that we change this culture so that error reporting happens as part of the application. The application should KNOW all the relevant information, i.e. platform etc etc... still ask the user what happened but logging in to bugzilla... oh please that's so last decade! It's a win-win to get this sorted, and I mean for ALL software... please spread the word. Forget web 2.0, we now needs Freeware 2.0 where this sort of thing is automatic. The only thing about bugzilla is that it really bugs me ;) I don't always have time to report bugs for ALL applications, so I only report about a third of bugs... I reckon some users don't even bother signing up to things like bugzilla... I reckon only 10% of people report bugs... but if we make it easy then 30% probably will. That's a three-fold increase! Let's start the trend. On 18 May 2010 12:48, Alan Ezust <alan.ezust@...> wrote:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Errors showing in status bar
mail.body: Hi, What you describe below is the right way to handle errors from the user's point of view, but there are a few points here that need to be taken into account: 1. This approach is more appropriate for commercially-supported applications. You mention eight thousand user accounts - what about the eight thousand developers to actually take a look at all these errors? 2. The access to SF is not simple. Filing a bug report automatically in SF probably has its share of additional problems. I'd be glad if we had some global database to which we could send information from jEdit in a simple way. I am looking for such a database not only for error reporting, but also for collecting statistical usage information. 3. Do you know which data should be collected? Mostly, we ask for the activity log file and the properties, sometimes also for buffer content. But these can contain some sensitive information, and is not always appropriate. If you have good solutions for the above, let me know... I'll be glad to help. Shlomy 2010/5/18 Mike <xandrani@...>:

mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] Fwd: Errors showing in status bar
mail.body: Sorry, broken mail headers somewhere - I expected "reply" to reply to list, not author... ---------- Forwarded message ---------- Date: 26 May 2010 18:08 Subject: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Errors showing in status bar An expected error can only be handled if someone has written the code to expect and handle it. If they haven't, the error is by definition * unexpected* - so it will propagate, and become a system error. If a condition that *should *be being handled by a friendly message is instead creating a system error, that is a bug, and should be reported. If a system error is occurring that *cannot* be replaced with a friendly message - well, that's a bug too, surely? In other words, fatal errors should always be reported as bugs if you can reproduce them. If the resolution to the bug is to show the user a friendly message - or even ignore the error and recover automatically - that is still a worthwhile bug report. Now, whether we should expect all "ordinary" users to see and deal with the fatal errors, I'm less sure. As Shlomy says, automatically filing error reports is not trivial, and sifting through them to find actual bugs even less so. I agree with you about making it easier to report bugs in Free Software ("Freeware" means something different, BTW), though, with caveats again about sifting effort. Just my 2-pence worth... -- Rowan Collins [IMSoP]

mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] middle-click a fold
mail.body: Hi I would just like to know if 'middle-clicking' the plus (expand?) icon in the gutter for a fold is coded into the core, or is configurable somewhere. Right now, middle-clicking the expand icon will narrow the view to that fold, but I would like to change it to fully expand the fold. Any ideas/tips/directions would be helpful. thanks James --

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] middle-click a fold
mail.body: Hm, we don't differentiate between left and middle mouse button currently. And Java sets the "Alt" modifier if the middle mouse button is pressed. So for jEdit pressing the middle mouse button is equal to holding "Alt" and pressing the left mouse button. The behaviour of that combination is not controllable through the settings dialog, but it is controlled via the property "view.gutter.AfoldClick" which you can set to any action you like. By default it is set to "narrow-fold". You may want to set it to "expand-fold". Regards Vampire James schrieb:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] middle-click a fold

Let me play around and see if I'm doing something wrong. thanks again James On Mon, May 24, 2010 at 6:12 PM, Vampire (jEdit) <Vampire0@...> wrote: --

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] middle-click a fold
mail.body: Ah, you are right. The actions set there are not the standard actions defined. In this context you can set the actions select-fold narrow-fold toggle-fold toggle-fold-fully match-struct narrow-struct So maybe you want to set it to "toggle-fold-fully" which is the default action for Shift+Click. Regards Vampire James schrieb:

mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] Weirdness with plugins
mail.body: I generally run the latest jEdit from either svn or the daily builds, so maybe that is the cause of my problem, but I thought I'd ask if anyone else has seen this issue before I write up a bug. I'm using the original docking framework. I have jEdit set up so that my plugins are docked either at the bottom or on the right side. (Screenshot: the buffer switcher to change to another file, the active plugins with change. For example, if Project Viewer is active on the right and Console is active on the bottom, I'll change files and suddenly the File Brower is active on the right and the Activity Log will be active on the bottom. Then I change to another file, and Project Viewer and Console are active again. This is not consistent behavior in that it doesn't always happen, but it happens a lot for me. Has anyone else seen this? Thanks, Dale

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Weirdness with plugins
mail.body: Hi Dale, Does this happen when the buffer mode is changed? If so, this behavior is most likely caused by the option "Automatically load mode-specific docking layout", in Global Options -> Docking. Shlomy 2010/5/19 Dale Anson <danson@...>:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Weirdness with plugins

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] SOLVED: Problem upgrading jEdit 4.2/Win XP to jEdit 4.3.1/Win 7
mail.body: Thanks to our jEdit experts for their quick and useful responses. All recognized that the mode file must contain an invalid character, at least if it is assumed to be in UTF-8 encoding. This is so because I am intentionally using characters in the range 0x80-0xFF of ISO-8859-1 and these presumably represent impossible values in UTF-8. However, the mode worked under jEdit 4.2 Final so encoding seemed to be the root cause. I took Vampire's advice and included `encoding="ISO-8859-1"` in the heading after which jEdit was immediately willing to read my mode files. [It doesn't like them for others reasons which I'm working my way through -- so far jEdit Help has provided the explanations.] Thanks Kazutoshi for clearing up the mystery of why my modes suddenly failed (4.3.1 is a better jEdit!). BTW, the sum total of my knowledge of XML comes from jEdit's Help file, and I may not be the only one in that boat. The section "The Preamble and MODE tag" makes no mention of the default encoding issue and what to do about it. It would be nice if Vampires's crystal clear explanation could make its way into the Help file. Kazutoshi's note would be useful too in case I'm not the the last in the world to be using 4.2 Final. Thanks again, George Hovey

Or try opening it in jEdit using ISO-8851 encoding and saving it. jEdit should tell you exactly where the error is then. On Tue, May 11, 2010 at 8:16 PM, George Hovey <ghova0@...> wrote:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Problem upgrading jEdit 4.2/Win XP to jEdit 4.3.1/Win 7
mail.body: Hi George, the mode files are XML files. If you don't specify an encoding in the XML file, XML files default to be UTF-8 encoded. If you save the mode file with ISO-8895-1, without specifying so in the XML file, while having some special characters in it that result in illegal UTF-8 sequences, this can happen. Actually I wonder that the same files work with 4.2final but not with 4.3.1. But maybe something got changed (read: fixed) here to behave correctly. Maybe you should try to either convert your mode files to UTF-8 or declare them to be ISO-8859-1 explicitly. If even this wont work, an example file that can be investigated would be helpful. Regards Vampire George Hovey schrieb:

mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] [ jEdit-announce ] jEdit 4.3.2 is out!
mail.body: Hi all, I proudly present 4.3.2 which came out now. Have fun with the new release. JEDIT 4.3 VERSION HISTORY Thanks to Björn "Vampire" Kautler, Matthieu Casanova, Shlomy Reinstein, Kazutoshi Satoda, oman002, and Eric Le Lay for contributing to this release. - Fixed Standalone TextArea build target (Shlomy Reinstein) - Fixed a NPE that happens when an error occurs before the view is loaded (Matthieu Casanova #2905487) - Fixed bug #2927555: beanshell load() fails w/ exception (Shlomy Reinstein) - Fixed a memory leak which held closed View and EditPane when using global bufferset scope. (Kazutoshi Satoda) - When removing text from the buffer, the event contentRemoved was sent before making the buffer dirty (oman002 #2944145) - Fixed leaky memory usage after some specific text operations. (Kazutoshi Satoda) - Worked around a memory leak in Sun Java 6 where the sun.font.GlyphLayout is cached and reused while holding an instance to the char array (Björn "Vampire" Kautler) - When setting a new message in the status bar in a macro called from the Macro menu the message was cleared immediately (Matthieu Casanova #2964522) - don't log an error when the API docs are not available. Provide a link to the online docs instead (SF.net bug #1777806 - Eric Le Lay) - RFC edit mode was misplaced in catalog and was never matching anything because text edit mode glob was more global and checked first (Matthieu Casanova) - java installer refuses to install from a directory containing exclamation marks (SF.net bug #2065330 - Eric Le Lay) - Applied patch #2932330 to suppress BufferUpdate messages from temporary buffers to improve performance. (Dale Anson) ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ _______________________________________________ jEdit Announcement List jEdit-announce@...

mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] p4 plugin question
mail.body: I've just started using the p4 plugin for a project at work. The directory structure looks like this: /home/whatever/workspace/mainproject /home/whatever/workspace/mainproject/project1 /home/whatever/workspace/mainproject/project2 ... I have a p4 config file in /home/whatever/workspace/mainproject, but in jEdit, I've set up my project (in ProjectViewer) to just work on /home/whatever/workspace/mainproject/project1. Doing p4 sync from ProjectViewer gives me an error executing perforce: Exit status: 1 Perforce client error: Connect to server failed; check $P4PORT. TCP connect to perforce failed. perforce: host unknown. Is it possible to have the p4 plugin run the p4 commands from the root directory of the project? If it would, then the commands would succeed without having to add a p4 config file to each subproject since p4 will check parent directories for the config file. Thanks, Dale

mail.body: Hi Dale, 2010/5/3 Dale Anson <danson@...>: That is exactly the set up I use at work and it works for me. Did you set up the "P4 Config" option in your project's properties? mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] buffer switcher not switching
mail.body: A bug has started happening in jEdit in the last week or so which I haven't seen before. Which is odd, because I don't remember doing anything to change my configuration recently. ("Remember" is probably the operative word...) Specifically, sometimes the buffer switcher doesn't work any more when I try to use it from the buffer switcher, i.e. by opening the buffer switcher drop-down at the top of the buffer and using 'up' or 'down' to move through the names of buffers. The name of the buffer changes, but the buffer remains the same. (I don't know what would happen if I made a change in an incorrectly labeled buffer--I'm afraid to do that for fear I'd lose the file on the server.) I believe View | Go to Previous/Next Buffer always works, but I use that so seldom that I can't say for sure. Some things which are perhaps non-standard about my setup: 1) I have jEdit partitioned vertically into three panes (I have large monitors :-) 2) I'm using the ftp plugin, and all the files reside on an ftp server 3) I have "Visible rows in buffer switcher" set to 100 (probably overkill) 4) "BufferSet scope for new EditPanes" is set to global 5) "Sort buffer sets" and "Sort buffer sets by file name" are both checked. This bug seems to happen sporadically. I had "View | Toggle buffer switcher" checked; I just now unchecked the box and re-checked it, and the switcher started working again. It's hard to fix a sporadic bug, I know...so if anyone else has seen this, or has suggestions on how to generate an error report the next time I see it, let me know. I'm using jEdit v4.3.2 in Windows Vista, Java 1.6.0_21. -- Mike Maxwell maxwell@...

Note that the activity log file is overwritten each time you run jEdit, so send it (or search for exceptions in it yourself) after you experience this problem but before you restart jEdit. mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Two questions
mail.body: Hi, To replicate a 4.2f setup with all the installed plugins, usually all that is needed is to install jEdit 4.2f in the new machine, and copy the jEdit settings directory (.jEdit under your user directory) and its sub-directories recursively to your home directory in the new machine. Would you mind sharing your problems with the upgrade to 4.3 with us? To be able to understand why jEdit freezes, it is strongly recommended to run jEdit from a console (e.g. Command Prompt on Windows). Then, when jEdit freezes, you can usually (depending on the Java implementation, I guess) click Ctrl+Break in the console to get a dump of all Java threads on the console. This can help find out what happened. In addition, the activity.log file (in the jEdit settings directory) can reveal exceptions or problems that were logged. If you can collect this data, you can either submit a bug report in the SourceForge tracker of jEdit, or, if you like, send it to me directly, or to jedit-devel (if you're subscribed to it). Thanks, Shlomy On Wed, Jul 21, 2010 at 2:49 PM, Zoltán Kócsi <zoltan@...> wrote:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Two questions
mail.body: If you are having crashes, it could be that you are trying to run some old plugins (such as docker) that no longer work on 4.3. I suggest you start with no plugins and install them all from the plugin manager.. If you can reproduce the crash, please submit a bug report and attach an activity log. If there are specific plugins/versions that were available on the plugin manager for 4.2 and are no longer, and you know what they are, you can let us know them and we can try to expose them via a branch again. I don't think any rugs were pulled out from under you. We're just not releasing newer plugins or bugfixes against it. On Wed, Jul 21, 2010 at 4:49 AM, Zoltán Kócsi <zoltan@...> wrote:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Two questions
mail.body: Hi there, in my opinion it is NOT strongly recommended, but strongly discouraged to run jEdit from a console. It is ugly and wastes space. Besides that, it doesn't bring ANY benefit. Yes, you can press C+Break on Windoze or C+\ on Linux directly, but that is a really small benefit that isn't very convenient either, especially as there are tools you can just start when you need them that do the job better. E. g. the shipped jvisualvm can take a thread dump or a heap dump from one of the running Java processes and save them in a file, ... Regards Vampire Shlomy Reinstein schrieb:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] [jEdit-users] problem with phpparser and clone method
mail.body: sbarex wrote (on 02/08/2010): What PHP version are you coding for? If I define the class below, I get a parser error from PHP if I try to compile it under PHP 5.2.13: class Foo Parse error: syntax error, unexpected T_CLONE, expecting T_STRING in /home/rowanc/tmp/clone.php on line 4 The only other way $object->clone() would make any sense would be if you'd defined __call() on the class, in which case it is apparently parseable, but it doesn't seem like a great idea. If it's a clone method, call it "__clone()", and use "clone $object" to call it; if it's not, call it something else. (I appreciate that it's not always as simple as that, and that may not be an option...) While it's arguably a bug that the jEdit parser treats this differently to PHP, I wouldn't be surprised to see PHP treating that syntax as invalid in a future version too. -- Rowan Collins Senior Developer | Click with Technology

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] [jEdit-users] problem with phpparser and clone method
mail.body: Ah, OK, in your second example, it looks like it's the brackets that are throwing it: it's probably misinterpreting "clone($object)" as a function call to the non-existent function clone(), where PHP5 sees it as "clone" [keyword] followed by "($object)" [expression in brackets] - like "echo ($x+1)". "return @clone $object;" shows as fine, and is probably better style for pure PHP5, although you can actually exploit the fact that clone ($object) looks like a function call to write code that runs in both PHP4 and PHP5. So we have 2 cases for a bug report, if anyone has a chance to look into them: // Uncommon, but used in popular IMagick extension; apparently interpretted as keyword, but actually method call // Uncommon, but used for PHP4 compatibility; apparently interpretted as function call, but actually keyword (I don't actually know anything about how this parser operates, but the above would be my guess as to roughly why these cases produce errors) Regards, Rowan sbarex wrote (on 06/08/2010):

mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] Syntax error highligting
mail.body: Hi All, I have just started using jEdit and so far I am loving it - I used to be an emacs/jSwat kinda developer, and I have just found Eclipse too irritating. It seems to me that most of those features I actually liked in Eclipse are available to a reasonable degree in jEdit+plugins. However, I'm not seeing any indication of syntax errors as I type code. So I was wondering if this is just a plugin or setting that I've missed, or whether it's something that just isn't available in jEdit. If it's not something that's available, is it something that anyone else would like to see in jEdit? My thoughts are to harness the syntax highlighter, and flag syntax that doesn't make sense to the highlighter as a warning/error. I am assuming that this could be implemented without trying to shoehorn a complete incremental compiler into jEdit (probably a bad idea), and instead leveraging code and features already there. Any and all comments welcome. Cheers! Nik

These will work as you type if you have them set to parse on keystroke. However, what you're proposing sounds like a more general solution and sounds like a good idea. mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] PHPParser and Sidekick methods list: suggestions for new features
mail.body: I develop very often in php using jedit with PHPParser and I use Sidekick to navigate quickly in the code. I think it would be useful to add a system which would include custom intems in the list of functions in the Sidekick. You could define a simple syntax to use within comments to be recognized by phpparser and displayed in the list of functions by way of comment (a similar use of #pragma directive in XCode that allows you to add a comment to appear on the list of methods defined in the file in order to group together pieces of code). I saw a similar function can be implemented using ctags instead phpparser to interpret the code. With following ctags invocation options: --PHP-kinds=+cfd-v --totals=yes --tag-relative=yes --regex-PHP=/[[:blank:]]*(#|\/\/|\/*)[[:blank:]]*pragma:(.*)/--\2--/pragma/ the parser recognizes the comments starting with "pragma:" and shows them in the list of methods such as a divider. But I believe thath Phpparser is more effective than ctags to parse php files. Thanks!

mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] Hiding regions of the buffer
mail.body: Hi, I'd like jEdit to be able to filter out regions of the buffer, so that I don't see them in the text area. The main purpose of this is for preprocessor conditionals in C/C++. Patterns like the following are quite popular in C/C++: #ifdef WIN32 .. do something that works on Windows ... #else .. do something that works on other operating systems ... #endif If I work on Windows, it would be very helpful for me to see only the 2nd line above, so that the rest of the text doesn't interfere while reading the buffer (visually). I'd like to be able to select a word (like WIN32) and have jEdit hide all lines that do not exist when this word is not defined for the preprocessor. This is probably a complex feature, and the main problem is that it can easily conflict with the folding mode. But for starters, I'd like to see how this really looks in tools (editors?) that already have such a feature. Does anyone know of such a tool? IDEs that I know (like Visual Studio) typically show all the text, but show the text I want to hide in gray (as an indication that this code doesn't really exist in the current configuration). I'd like to take this one step further and completely hide this text. Other uses of this feature would be similar to the Mylyn plugin in eclipse, which hides text that has never been visited or is rarely visited. Thanks, Shlomy

mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] waitForConsole
mail.body: I'm trying to write a macro that runs multiple commands in the system shell in the console plugin using "runCommandInConsole". I used to use "waitForConsole" to make sure that the previous command had completed before running the next command, but it's now giving me problems. The "waitForConsole" command locks up jEdit. If I don't use this in my macro, only the first command actually gets run by the console. I'm running jEdit 4.4pre1 on Windows XP SP3, Java 1.6.0_21. Is there another way to do this? Any help would be appreciated. Thanks, Forrest Sent from my PC.

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] waitForConsole
mail.body: Your macro runs in the UI thread. Unless you create a new thread for this purpose in your macro, the jEdit window will hang until "waitForConsole" returns. This might be a deadlock if the console needs to do something in the UI thread. If that is the case, create a Runnable in your macro for this purpose, and use ThreadUtilities.runInBackground(runnable) to run it. Hope this helps. I don't know how it previously worked. Sounds like either your macro used to run it in the background, or "waitForConsole" used to do that in previous versions of Console. Shlomy

It could be related to the particular combination of plugins you are using and/or the edit mode you are in so this is a tricky one to track down. But I've seen it too. it's in the FAQ actually. mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Autocompletion...
mail.body: SideKick settings are found in jEdit at: Plugins->Plugin Options->SideKick "Show completion popups where possible" must be checked for the completion to work. "Parse on buffer switch and save" is recommended for JavaSideKick in general. "Parse on keystroke" is recommended for completion to work well. You'll probably need to play with the "After last keystroke, wait (second)" and "After popup trigger keystroke, wait (second)" settings. For me, I've got "After last keystroke" set to 0.75 sec and "After popup trigger" set to 0.25 sec. You'll want to adjust based your typing speed, machine speed, and coding style. mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Plugin Update / Install - PHPParser
mail.body: Hi Patrik, On Wed, Sep 8, 2010 at 11:50 PM, Patrik Plihal <patrik.plihal@...: Correct. The plugin release was reverted back to 1.2.7 until the developer gets some confirmations regarding his fix. Technically, the broken 1.3.0 files should still be available if you go download them manually. Plugin Manager has been set to download the 1.2.7 version, so all the mirrors should have the same old 1.2.7 files still there. I did not "re-release" 1.2.7. So, they should be perfectly fine to use. It's mostly a manual process. Once the plugin developer creates a ticket under the Plugin Release tracker, I manually run some automated scripts to: download, compile, package, and install the plugin for testing. If all looks good, I put the artifacts on sf.net for distribution on the mirrors. Note that "real" testing is mostly left to the developer, and users who are building from source (trunk). I mostly just check to make sure that it all compiles fine, installs without any errors, has a help file, and that menu's and options don't generate any errors. I don't do any "real" testing of the plugins, so occasionally errors happen. There are some daily builds available if you'd like a package that you can unzip in your [jedit settings]/jars directory. These are compiled and prepared using the aforementioned automated scripts, whenever code is checked into the trunk, and are available here: The PHPParser specifically, available here: Hope that helps. Eric -- Learn from the past. Live in the present. Plan for the future. Blog:

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] ubuntu 10.10 and java version problem
mail.body: Neither the script that uses the java-wrappers, nor the script that resides in ~/bin has anything to do with official jEdit development. They are not put in place by the official DEB installer we provide in our own repository. If some package puts those files in place, then those are packages from someone else like Ubuntu/Canonical and problems with them have to be reported against them. I'm sorry, but we have no control over such packages. mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] Using jEdit on a widescreen
mail.body: I am about to buy a new laptop and they all have "wide" screens. Since I use a relatively large font, the shortened height of these screens means that I will see fewer lines in a text area and this is serious for editing latex documents or computer programs. Does anyone have any suggestions of how to utilize the extra width of the screen to make up for the lower height? I see that I can open new views or split views into panes, but I can't see much difference between them in terms of the editing experience. What considerations should guide the choice of one over the other? But ... I don't usually work on two files simultaneously or two portions of a file, so what I would really like is for a continuous portion of text to be shown in two side-by-side textareas, while the movement of the caret or the scolling is synchronized. Is that possible? Thanks Moti

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Using jEdit on a widescreen
mail.body: Hi, Please see my reply below, in between your text. Shlomy Moti.Ben-Ari@...> wrote: You can add dockable windows to the right and left of the edit pane (or text area). Some dockables provide you with quick navigation. For example: - SideKick provides a tree layout of the current buffer. For source code, you can usually use CtagsSideKick to show you the list of source code elements in the buffer and use a single click to jump to them. - The jEdit Markers (or the MarkerSets plugin) can let you quickly jump to places in the code where you've added markers. - Hypersearch / LucenePlugin show you the results of a search and let you jump quickly to each of the results. I usually use SideKick + CtagsSideKick for quick navigation of source code. I see that I can open new views or split views into panes, but I can't see A view is another top-level window (which would normally appear in you task bar as another task). As such it takes more screen space (e.g. its own title, menu, frame, dockables etc). Splitting a view into panes just requires a separator line between the panes. That's an interesting idea, but unfortunately there is not such feature currently in jEdit. I haven't checked, but it might be easy to set up such a thing using a BeanShell macro - splitting the edit pane vertically, setting the top displayed line to be the next line after the lowest displayed line in the other pane, and finally synchronizing the scrollbars (this "finally" is the most complex part but it might be easy - need to check the code for that). Thanks

mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] Edit mode for specific file extensions
mail.body: Hi, I am using JEdit on Linux. Many times I edit *.conf files, and usually I change the Edit mode to shellscript (By Utilities->Buffer Options->Edit Mode). In this way, commented lines (which start with #) are colored differently , and viewing the file this way seems to me much better. I want that permanently, files which are ended with .conf will have shellscript edit mode. Can this be achieved ? Rgs, Mark

mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Edit mode for specific file extensions
mail.body: Yes. Go to global options, editing. Click the dropdown for 'change settings for mode' and select shellscript. Uncheck 'use default settings' and add .conf to the file globs. mail.header: Re: [ jEdit-users ] Edit mode for specific file extensions
mail.body: Yes, go to Utilities, Global Options, Editing, then select 'shellscript' from the top dropdown, uncheck 'Use default settings', then add .conf to the file name glob. Dale On Thu, Dec 16, 2010 at 10:22 PM, Mark Ryden <markryde@...> wrote:

mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] [ jEdit-announce ] jEdit 4.4 is released!
mail.body: jEdit 4.4 version history :encoding=UTF-8: Thanks to Björn "Vampire" Kautler, Alan Ezust, Eric Berry, Shlomy Reinstein, Damien Radtke, Dale Anson, Matthieu Casanova, Eric Le Lay, Bernhard Walle, Joerg Spieler, Kevin Hunter, François Rey, Dion Whitehead, Marcelo Vanzin, Jesse Pavel, Bernhard Walle and Jakub Roztočil for contributing to this release. - Fixed an exception when trying to add new menu items to the context menu if some ActionSets have been unloaded (plugin deactivation) (Matthieu Casanova #3071355) - Windows installer kills existing jEdit instance before trying to install (#2617610 - Eric Le Lay) - Closes menus when toggling dockables. (#3022084 - Anshal Shukla) - VFSBrowser escape handling fixed when used as a dialog (#3101808 - Alan Ezust) - Context menu sorted when adding toolbar buttons (#3074164 - Alan Ezust) - Fixed an exception when clicking ok while adding new action to the context menu if no action has been selected (Matthieu Casanova #3072546) - Fixed TextArea.selectBlock() when the block is at offset 0 (Jesse Pavel #3062072) - Fixed a memory leak in the beanshell snippet replacement (Matthieu Casanova #3043132) - The "buffer" variable is always the current buffer and not the buffer where the replacement occurs when using beanshell snippet replacement (Matthieu Casanova #3043118) - Removed workaround in drag & drop code of TextArea that doesn't seem useful anymore on Ubuntu and cause exceptions when dropping a Transferable that is not a String but has a java.io.InputStream as representation class (Matthieu Casanova) - Fixed caret going to the wrong position when adding explicit folds in a buffer that uses an edit mode that has no line comment (Matthieu Casanova #2138160) - Fixed caret going after the explicit folds when adding explicit folds to the wrong position when adding explicit folds while having no selection, in any edit mode (Matthieu Casanova) - When saving a buffer the autoreload option of the buffer was overridden by global settings (Matthieu Casanova #2999966) - Improve indentation settings of the shellscript edit mode. (Björn "Vampire" Kautler #3005463) - Removed the duplicated "Architecture" line from the Debian control file. (Björn "Vampire" Kautler #2999456) - In the manage panel, when selecting a library, the description panel do not contains "null" for every fields and the title is set to the jar name instead of "null" (Matthieu Casanova) - Update of textarea scrollbars and bufferSwitcher are now done in EventQueue thread (Matthieu Casanova #2946031) - Removed unnecessary popup warnings from InstallPanel when loading a pluginset. (Alan Ezust) - fix #1439605 - remove installer.VariableGridLayout (r16596). - Fixed bug in "selection-length" status bar widget: The widget was not added to the edit bus, so it wasn't updated when the edit pane changed. (Shlomy Reinstein) - Removed write capability to the UrlVFS. Now http:// files are marked read-only. (Eric Le Lay #2805986) - When having two monitors the About dialog was appearing between them, one half on each monitor. Now it's position is relative to the active View (Matthieu Casanova) - Selection foreground color broken when soft wrap. (Shlomy Reinstein #2946203) - Using regex style encoding auto detectors, StringIndexOutOfBoundsException could happen when loading a file. (Kazutoshi Satoda) - The encoding could be less accurate when opening a file from File System Browser. (SF.net bug #1524181,1721796 - Kazutoshi Satoda) - ALT key typing with Windows Look&Feel (for menu bar interaction) now behaves a bit closer to native Windows applications. NOTE: It's still incomplete due to some problems in JVM. (SF.net bug #2795635 - Kazutoshi Satoda) - HelpViewer loads pages asynchronously (SF.net bug #1231914 - Eric Le Lay) - Don't replace colons by slashes in canonPath() on Mac OS X (SF.net bug #1488911 - Eric Le Lay - r17754) - Fix Angle brackets showing up in plugin descriptions in plugin manager (SF.net bug #1963667 - Eric Le Lay) - Fix SOCKS proxy accessing wrong property. Therefore, SOCKS proxy was never getting enabled. (SF.net patch #2820969 - Milutin Jovanović) - CopyFileWorker now throws a FileNotFoundException instead of a NPE if the target path is not a directory and it's parent doesn't exists. - CopyFileWorker do not accept that the source and target are the same (Matthieu Casanova) - Changed GUIUtilities.confirm() to work also from worker threads, by deferring the confirmation dialog to the EDT. This fixes threading issues with HyperSearchRequest, if the number of results exceeds the "max results" option. (Shlomy Reinstein) - Fix "-reuseview" not bringing the view to the front. (Sf.net bug #1510651 - Shlomy Reinstein) - Show search bar in full screen mode. (Sf.net bug #2944752 - Shlomy Reinstein) - Added methods to manage the cursor if the TextArea : In the TextAreaPainter class, added resetCursor() setCursor(Cursor) The cursor behavior is the following : when the cursor is the default one : TEXT_CURSOR, when typing text it is hidden, after moving the mouse it reappears. If a plugin calls setCursor() to replace it for whatever reason, the cursor will not disappear anymore when typing or be changed to TEXT_CURSOR until resetCursor() is called (Matthieu Casanova) - Introduction of a new ThreadUtilities class implementing a - Made method TextUtilities.getCharType() public (Matthieu Casanova) - Method MiscUtilities.formatFileSize() moved to StandardUtilities (Matthieu Casanova) - New method E ServiceManager.getService(Class<E> clazz, String name) to get service instance (Matthieu Casanova) - Register api changed, it now contains Transferable (Matthieu Casanova) - Added ThreadUtilities utility class (Matthieu Casanova) - Removed deprecated objectfactory xml parser. - File System Browser dynamic menu support (#2938170 - François Rey) - Added a method for unregistering macro handlers: Macros.unregisterHandler(). - bufferSet api rewritten. Now each editPane have its own bufferSet, does not share it with other editPanes. The bufferset scope is the same for all EditPanes. (Matthieu Casanova) - Status bar widget : it is now possible to use labels starting with letters in status bar. (Matthieu Casanova) - Removed long deprecated TextArea#isDragInProgress() and TextArea#setDragInProgress(). (SF.net patch #2809776,2936146 - Kevin Hunter) - EditBus.send() will now always deliver messages on the AWT thread, although it can be called from any thread. (Marcelo Vanzin) - Added EditBus.sendAsync(): this just enqueues messages to be send over the EditBus as soon as the AWT thread is not busy, and returns immediately. (Marcelo Vanzin) - Added ability to tag classes with EditBus.EBHandler. This is only useful when tagging an EditPlugin class, and makes the plugin instance behave as if it implemented EBComponent (it's added to the bus when the plugin is activated). (Marcelo Vanzin) - RFC edit mode was misplaced in catalog and was never matching anything because text edit mode glob was more global and checked first (Matthieu Casanova) - New ping-pong list component org.gjt.sp.jedit.gui.PingPongList (Matthieu Casanova) - PluginUpdate bus message now have a method getPluginVersion() that returns the plugin version if there is one (Matthieu Casanova #2953163) - Added StyleEditor.invokeForCaret(textArea) which does same as buffer.editSyntaxStyle(textArea) did, but can be invoked without specifying the buffer object carefully. (Kazutoshi Satoda) - HistoryModel's max size is no more defined globally : replaced the static max variable by a per-instance max variable and a static defaultMax variable (Eric Le Lay) - The JeditBuffer class now have thread-safe getText() params-less convenience method (Vadim Voituk) - Patch 3008954 to Mode and ModeProvider to allow an exact filename match when selecting the mode for a file. (Patch provided by Bernhard Walle) - Patch 3022084 added View.closeAllMenus(). (Anshal Shukla) - Update for Stata-edit mode (goebbe, # 3019042) - Added visualbasic.xml edit mode (Anonymous submitter, #3031412) - Added haxe.xml and hxml mode files to support haXe language (Dion Whitehead, François Rey, # 2922986) - Added plaintex.xml mode file, for plain tex files. (# 2787012 - James Nicholl) - nsis2.xml update (#2653404 Uwe donovaly) - sas.xml update (#2926121, 3015899 - goebbe) - html.erb added to rhtml mode catalog entry. (# 2734062 Sergey Mezentsev) - Added Go edit mode (#2898646 - Jim Lawton) - When pasting text copied from the textarea, if the target textarea has no edit mode, the edit mode from the source is copied (Matthieu Casanova) - Added the missing doxygen commands for doxygen v1.6.1 (bug #2895272 - report and patch from Bernhard Walle). doxygen now highlights quoted strings in comments. - Ruby mode - keyword highlighting bug fix ( # 2868654 - Suraj Kurapati) - Updated logtalk.xml file (# 2937909 - Paulo Moura) - Slax Edit Mode ( # 2883030 - curtis_call ) - Json edit mode ( # 2979745 - Dale Anson ) - PHP Smarty Templates Mode ( # 2969956 - Rowan Collins) - Haskell edit mode rewrite ( # 2993269 - Stephen Blackheath) - Pure edit mode updates ( # 2988741 - asitdepends) - url.xml mode (# 1991306 - Kevin Hunter) - LaTeX mode - code indentation (2872638 - Michael Schlotter) (#3008614 - Robin Neatherway) - Added logtalk.xml mode file (#1945284 - Paulo Moura) - Added regex.xml mode file (#2782258 - Kevin Hunter) - Added sip.xml mode file to read sip messages (Matthieu Casanova) - New paste special action accessible from menu Edit->More clipboard->Paste Special that will suggest different mode to paste data from clipboard, currently plain text, rich jEdit text (plain text + edit mode) and mime type html are supported (Matthieu Casanova) - Added Ant mode file for Ant build files. (#3016053 - Dale Anson) - Added TLD mode file for JSP Tag Definition Library files. (#3016054 - Dale Anson) - Added Maven mode file for Maven pom.xml files. (#3016057 - Dale Anson) - Updated javacc mode to better highlight keywords and regular expressions. (Dale Anson) - Updated Django temlate mode to Django 1.2, added missing keywords and better integration with HTML, CSS and JS (Jakub Roztočil) - Wrap mode tooltip in status bar now indicates the current wrap mode (Matthieu Casanova) - It is now possible to copy several files in the VFS Browser at the same time, and copy from/to the OS explorer (Matthieu Casanova) - Removed LatestVersion plugin. - HelpViewer font can be configured via Appearance Option Pane. (#3002186 - Alan Ezust) - Added actions for eating whitespace at word ends in both directions for findWordStart. (#1953341 - strank) - Added a configurable selection foreground color. If set, this color will be used for the selection foreground instead of the syntax highlighting color. The new option can be set from Global Options -> Text Area. (Shlomy Reinstein) - Implemented feature request #2919875: Namable views. You can now specify a name for each view using View -> Set view title. The name is persistent in the perspective.xml file. - In Hypersearchs result panel, the query string length is now limited to 100 chars by default for display (Matthieu Casanova) - Applied patch #2887520: Allow filtering the recent file list using file globs, - New status bar widget design (Matthieu Casanova #1540560) - New Encodings option pane using drag & drop (Matthieu Casanova) - Parsing buffer local properties is limited to the first 10000 characters of the first and last 10 lines. This is a performance enhancement when loading buffers containing very long lines (Matthieu Casanova) . Added a new option to perform font substitution in the text area when the current configured font can't display characters in the buffer. It's disabled by default, and can be enabled in the text area option pane, along with the option to choose preferred fonts for substitution. This makes reading files which contain text in multiple scripts more bearable. (Marcelo Vanzin) - Fixed ModeCatalogHandler so if an edit mode in the user-specific catalog has the same name as an edit mode in the system catalog, the version in the user-specific catalog will override the system default. This is what the documentation for writing an edit mode has stated is true for some time, now it is. (Dale Anson) - Gave better priorities within modes which matches with a file at the same time, as the following order: - exact filename match - both the filename glob and the first line glob - only the filename glob - the first line glob (Dale Anson) - In status bar option pane, when adding a widget only widgets that are not already in the bar will be proposed (Matthieu Casanova feature #2937286) - Added jedit.exe in the Windows installer, so that users can invoke jEdit more like a native application. (Feature Request #2661227, Patch #2984552 - Hisateru Tanaka) - Added some more encoding detectors as default. (Kazutoshi Satoda) - Extended the scope of the workaround for a bug in Sun (and Apple) JVM 5 to cover IBM JVM because the same problem was reported on it. (SF.net bug #3006686 - Kazutoshi Satoda) - Added settings to Activity Log to adjust colors and filter by message type. (Dale Anson) - Updated 'Make Get and Set' macro. (Dale Anson) - Ctrl-P and Ctrl-N work from completion popups now (#3080463 - Damien Radtke) - Added "Replace" button to Search and Replace dialog. This allows a 'replace once' as opposed to 'replace and find'. mail.header: [ jEdit-users ] question about losing focus when upgrading to jre 1.5/jre 1.6
mail.body: Hello, I have a linux machine with jedit (4.2) and java 1.4. When I upgraded to java 1.5 I had this annoying problem: I loose focus when I switch from one application to another and then return to jedit. What I mean that in such a scenarion, when I return to JEdit, and press ctrl/f for search, the focus **is not** on the dialog box. I have to move the mouse pointer to the search box. And this is **very very** annoying. Moreover, I tried to upgrade to higher versions of JEdit (which must have JAVA 1.5 or 1.6) and still this same problem exist. Any idea ? this hinders me from upgrading to newer version of JEdit (higer than 4.2) Rgs, Mark
